Second-Order Guarantees in Federated Learning

Abstract

Federated learning is a useful framework for centralized learning from distributed data under practical considerations of heterogeneity, asynchrony, and privacy. Federated architectures are frequently deployed in deep learning settings, which generally give rise to non-convex optimization problems. Nevertheless, most existing analysis are either limited to convex loss functions, or only establish first-order stationarity, despite the fact that saddle-points, which are first-order stationary, are known to pose bottlenecks in deep learning. We draw on recent results on the second-order optimality of stochastic gradient algorithms in centralized and decentralized settings, and establish second-order guarantees for a class of federated learning algorithms.

1 Introduction

Federated learning pursues solutions to global optimization problems over distributed collections of agents by relying on the exchange of model updates in lieu of raw data. Federated architectures are frequently deployed in highly heterogeneous environments, where different agents have access to data of varying quality and varying computational resources. Performance guarantees for federated architectures are generally limited to convex loss functions, or to establishing limiting first-order stationarity on non-convex losses. First-order stationary points include minima, but can be saddle-points or local maxima as well. Saddle-points in particular have been identified as bottlenecks for optimization algorithms in many important applications, such as deep learningÂ [2, 3]. It is hence desirable to devise algorithms and performance analyses that ensure efficient escape from saddle-points despite high levels of asynchrony and heterogeneity. Recent works have identified gradient perturbations as playing a key role in guaranteeing efficient saddle-points escape in centralized and fully decentralized architecturesÂ [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]. Here, we establish analogous results in the federated learning framework, extending recent analysis fromÂ [1] to allow for multiple local updates.

Specifically, we consider a collection of Kğ¾K agents, where each agent kğ‘˜k is equipped with a risk loss function Jkâ€‹(w)subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¤J_{k}(w), which is defined as the expectation of a loss Qâ€‹(w;\xk)ğ‘„ğ‘¤subscript\xğ‘˜Q(w;\x_{k}):

Jkâ€‹(w)â‰œ\E\xkâ€‹Qâ€‹(w;\xk)â‰œsubscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¤subscript\Esubscript\xğ‘˜ğ‘„ğ‘¤subscript\xğ‘˜J_{k}(w)\triangleq\E_{\x_{k}}Q(w;\x_{k}) (1)

Here, Qâ€‹(w;\xk)ğ‘„ğ‘¤subscript\xğ‘˜Q(w;\x_{k}) quantifies the fit of the model parametrization wğ‘¤w to the random data \xksubscript\xğ‘˜\x_{k}. Note that we allow for the data \xksubscript\xğ‘˜\x_{k} to vary with the agent index kğ‘˜k, resulting in different risk functions Jkâ€‹(w)subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¤J_{k}(w) at different agents. It is common in multi-agent settings to pursue a model wosuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘œw^{o} that performs well on average by solving:

woâ‰œ\argminwâ€‹âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹Jkâ€‹(w)â‰œsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘œsubscript\argminğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¤w^{o}\triangleq\argmin_{w}\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}J_{k}(w) (2)

where the {pk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{p_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} denote non-negative weights, normalized to add up to one without loss of generality. It is common to let pk=1Ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ¾p_{k}=\frac{1}{K}, hence giving equal weight to every agent kğ‘˜k. In settings where agents are heterogeneous, and exhibit varying amounts of data, or varying computational capabilities, heterogeneous weights pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} can result in improved performance, which we allow for generality. Perhaps the most straightforward approach to pursuing wosuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘œw^{o} is by means of gradient descent, applied directly toÂ (2), resulting in:

wi=wiâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(wiâˆ’1)=wiâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹âˆ‡Jâ€‹(wiâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1ğœ‡âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1w_{i}=w_{i-1}-\mu\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1})=w_{i-1}-\mu\nabla J(w_{i-1}) (3)

where we defined Jâ€‹(â‹…)â‰œâˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹Jkâ€‹(â‹…)â‰œğ½â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ½ğ‘˜â‹…J(\cdot)\triangleq\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}J_{k}(\cdot). This implementation has two important drawbacks, which render it impractical in a federated learning setting. First, it requires full agent participation at every iteration, by means of computation and communication of âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(wiâˆ’1)âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1}) with a central aggregator. In federated learning applications, where agents may or may not be able to participate in the update at any given iteration, this can cause bottlenecks. Second, evaluation of the exact gradient âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(wiâˆ’1)âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1}) may be infeasible or costly, since it depends on the full distribution of \xksubscript\xğ‘˜\x_{k} through its expectation inÂ (1).

1.1 Related Works

Distributed algorithms for solving aggregate optimization problems similar toÂ (2) can be broadly classified into those that involve communication with a centralized parameter serverÂ [11, 12, 13, 14], and those that operate in a fully decentralized manner through peer-to-peer interactionsÂ [15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. Federated Averaging (FedAvg) was introduced inÂ [20], and has sparked a number of studies and extensions, including FedDaneÂ [21], FedProxÂ [22], hierarchical FedAvgÂ [23], and dynamic FedAvgÂ [24]. While the pursuit of an optimal average model as inÂ (2) is most common, multi-task variations have been introduced as well, both in a federatedÂ [25] and decentralized settingsÂ [26].

Most prior works on federated learning and the FedAvg algorithm focus on convex risk functionsÂ [13, 14, 24], or establish first-order stationarity in non-convex environmentsÂ [27, 28, 29, 21, 22, 23]. On the other hand, saddle points, which are first-order stationary, have been identified as bottlenecks in many learning applications, including deep learningÂ [2]. This contrast to the empirical success of deep learning has motivated a number of recent works to consider the ability of gradient descent algorithms to escape saddle-points and find â€œgoodâ€ local minima, both in centralizedÂ [30, 4, 31, 5, 6, 7, 8] and decentralized settingsÂ [32, 33, 9, 10]. The broad take-away from these works is that perturbations, either to the initialization or gradient updates, play a key role in pushing iterates away from strict-saddle points and toward local minimizers. In this work, we extend these results to the federated learning setting, where agents may take an arbitrary number of local steps before communicating with the central parameter server.

2 Algorithm Formulation

2.1 The Federated Averaging Scheme

The need for full and exact agent participation in evaluatingÂ (3) in a federated setting is addressed in the stochastic federated averaging (FedAvg) frameworkÂ [20]. To this end, the parameter server selects at iteration iğ‘–i a subset of Lğ¿L agents, collected in the set ğ’©isubscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}_{i}. We introduce a random indicator variable ğŸ™k,isubscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–\mathds{1}_{k,i}, which indicates whether agent kğ‘˜k participates at time iğ‘–i, i.e., ğŸ™k,i=1âŸºkâˆˆğ’©iâŸºsubscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–1ğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathds{1}_{k,i}=1\Longleftrightarrow k\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, and 00 otherwise. We assume for simplicity that agents are sampled uniformly at random, resulting in:

Prâ€‹{ğŸ™k,i=1}=\Eâ€‹{ğŸ™k,i}=LKPrsubscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–1\Esubscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ¾\mathrm{Pr}\left\{\mathds{1}_{k,i}=1\right\}=\E\left\{\mathds{1}_{k,i}\right\}=\frac{L}{K} (4)

Then, the parameter server provides participating agents with the current aggregate model \wiâˆ’1subscript\wğ‘–1\w_{i-1}. They use the model to initialize their local iterate to \wk,0=\wiâˆ’1subscript\wğ‘˜0subscript\wğ‘–1\w_{k,0}=\w_{i-1} and then perform Eksubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜E_{k} local stochastic update steps for e=1,â€¦,Ekğ‘’1â€¦subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜e=1,\ldots,E_{k}:

\wk,e=\wk,eâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹ğŸ™k,iâ€‹pkEkâ€‹âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1ğœ‡ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\w_{k,e}=\w_{k,e-1}-\mu K\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (5)

Here, âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) denotes a generic stochastic approximation of the gradient âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}). Using realizations for the random variable \xksubscript\xğ‘˜\x_{k}, it is common to construct âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)â‰œâˆ‡Qâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1,\xk,e)â‰œsuperscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1âˆ‡ğ‘„subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1subscript\xğ‘˜ğ‘’\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})\triangleq\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e}), resulting in stochastic gradient descent â€” we will discuss other constructions and their advantages in SectionÂ 2.2 below. The updated models are then fused by the central aggregator according to:

\wi=1Lâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KğŸ™k,iâ€‹\wk,Eksubscript\wğ‘–1ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscript\wğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜\w_{i}=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\w_{k,E_{k}} (6)

where ğ’—k,esubscriptğ’—ğ‘˜ğ‘’\boldsymbol{v}_{k,e} denotes i.i.d. perturbation noise with zero mean, following for example a Gaussian or Laplacian distribution.\qed {example}[Straggling Agents] Consider a setting where agents may be unreliable, in the sense that, despite being chosen by the parameter server to participate at iteration iğ‘–i, they may fail to return a locally updated model \wk,Eksubscript\wğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜\w_{k,E_{k}} by the time the server needs to re-aggregate models inÂ (6). Here, the scaling factor 1Î´k1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜\frac{1}{\delta_{k}} has been added to ensure unbiased gradient approximations, by allowing agents who participate less frequently to take larger steps. Alternative stochastic models for asynchronous behavior are possible as wellÂ [35].\qed It can be readily verified, that all three constructions in ExamplesÂ 2.2â€“8 are unbiased approximations of the true gradient âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}), i.e.:

\Eâ€‹{âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)|\wk,eâˆ’1}=âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)\Econditional-setsuperscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\E\left\{\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})|\w_{k,e-1}\right\}=\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}) (10)

\sk,eâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)â‰œâˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)â‰œsubscript\sğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})\triangleq\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})-\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}) (11)

is smooth:

â€–Rs,kâ€‹(x)âˆ’Rs,kâ€‹(y)â€–â‰¤Î²Râ€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–Î³normsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘¦subscriptğ›½ğ‘…superscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ›¾\|R_{s,k}(x)-R_{s,k}(y)\|\leq\beta_{R}{\|x-y\|}^{\gamma} (16)

for some Î²Rsubscriptğ›½ğ‘…\beta_{R} and 0<Î³â‰¤40ğ›¾40<\gamma\leq 4, and there is a gradient noise component (in the aggregate) in every direction:

Rs,kâ€‹(x)â‰¥Ïƒâ„“2â€‹I,âˆ€xsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœâ„“2ğ¼for-allğ‘¥R_{s,k}(x)\geq\sigma_{\ell}^{2}I,\ \ \ \forall\ x (17)
\qed

RelationÂ (12) ensures that the stochastic gradient approximation is unbiased, whileÂ (13) imposes a relative bound on the fourth-order momentÂ [17]. In light of Jensenâ€™s inequality, it is stronger than imposing a bound on the gradient noise variance, but will allow us to more granularly study the impact of the gradient noise around saddle-points; on the other hand, it is weaker than the more common conditions of bounded noise with probability one, or a sub-Gaussian conditionÂ [6, 7]. RelationÂ (16) ensures that the distribution of the stochastic gradient noise process is locally smooth, allowing us to formulate an accurate short-term model around saddle-pointsÂ [8]. It has previously been utilized to analyze in detail the steady-state behavior of stochastic gradient algorithms in convex environmentsÂ [17]. The persistent noise conditionÂ (17) will allow recursions to efficiently escape saddle-points by relying on the aggregate effect of the noise coupled with the local instability of saddle-points. It can be relaxed to only require a noise component to be present in the subspace of local descent directionsÂ [5, 8]. SinceÂ (17) can always be ensured by adding a small amount of isotropic perturbations to the stochastic gradient update as inÂ (8), it will be sufficient, for simplicity, to imposeÂ (17) in this work.

3 Performance Analysis

3.1 A Perturbed Centralized Gradient Recursion

By iteratingÂ (5), we find for the final local update \wk,Eksubscript\wğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜\w_{k,E_{k}} sent back to the parameter server:

\wk,Ek=\wiâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹ğŸ™k,iâ€‹pkEkâ€‹âˆ‘e=1Ekâˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)subscript\wğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘–1ğœ‡ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\w_{k,E_{k}}=\w_{i-1}-\mu K\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (18)

and after aggregation inÂ (6):

\wi=\wiâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹KLâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KğŸ™k,iâ€‹pkEkâ€‹âˆ‘e=1Ekâˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)subscript\wğ‘–subscript\wğ‘–1ğœ‡ğ¾ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1\displaystyle\w_{i}=\w_{i-1}-\mu\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (19)

We can reformulate this recursion to resemble the deterministic recursionÂ (3) as:

\wi=\wiâˆ’1âˆ’Î¼â€‹âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(\wiâˆ’1)âˆ’Î¼â€‹ğ’”iâˆ’Î¼â€‹ğ’…isubscript\wğ‘–subscript\wğ‘–1ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜subscript\wğ‘–1ğœ‡subscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğ’…ğ‘–\w_{i}=\w_{i-1}-\mu\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\nabla J_{k}(\w_{i-1})-\mu\boldsymbol{s}_{i}-\mu\boldsymbol{d}_{i} (20)

where ğ’”isubscriptğ’”ğ‘–\boldsymbol{s}_{i} and ğ’…isubscriptğ’…ğ‘–\boldsymbol{d}_{i} are perturbation terms:

\siâ‰œâ‰œsubscript\sğ‘–absent\displaystyle\s_{i}\triangleq KLâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KğŸ™k,iâ€‹pkEkâ€‹âˆ‘e=1Ekâˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wiâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‡Jâ€‹(\wiâˆ’1)ğ¾ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘–1âˆ‡ğ½subscript\wğ‘–1\displaystyle\>\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{i-1})-\nabla J(\w_{i-1}) (21)
ğ’…iâ‰œâ‰œsubscriptğ’…ğ‘–absent\displaystyle\boldsymbol{d}_{i}\triangleq KLâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KğŸ™k,iâ€‹pkEkâ€‹âˆ‘e=1Ek(âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wiâˆ’1))ğ¾ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’1superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘–1\displaystyle\>\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\left(\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})-\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{i-1})\right) (22)

ComparingÂ (20) withÂ (3), we observe that the FedAvg implementation can be viewed as a perturbed gradient descent recursion. Perturbations have recently been shown to be instrumental in allowing local descent algorithms to escape from saddle-points and converge to local minima of non-convex loss functions. However, those studies are generally limited to assuming unbiased perturbations. In contrast, employingÂ (5) with Ek>1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜1E_{k}>1 results in biased gradient perturbations resulting from the term ğ’…isubscriptğ’…ğ‘–\boldsymbol{d}_{i}, rendering current analyses inapplicable. In this work, we generalize recent results on the second-order guarantees of stochastic gradient algorithmsÂ [8] to allow for biased gradient perturbations, and recover second-order guarantees for the FedAvg algorithm for heterogeneous agents. We describe and discuss the dependence of these guarantees on the various parameters of the architecture, such as agent participation rate, levels heterogeneity, asynchrony, and computational capabilities.

We introduce the following smoothness conditions to ensure that the impact of the perturbationsÂ (21)â€“(22) is limited. {assumption}[Smoothness] The local costs Jkâ€‹(w)subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¤J_{k}(w) are assumed to be smooth:

â€–âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(y)â€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¦\displaystyle\left\|\nabla J_{k}(x)-\nabla J_{k}(y)\right\| â‰¤Î´â€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–absentğ›¿normğ‘¥ğ‘¦\displaystyle\leq\delta\left\|x-y\right\| (23)
â€–âˆ‡2Jkâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡2Jkâ€‹(y)â€–normsuperscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¦\displaystyle\left\|\nabla^{2}J_{k}(x)-\nabla^{2}J_{k}(y)\right\| â‰¤Ïâ€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–absentğœŒnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦\displaystyle\leq\rho\left\|x-y\right\| (24)

Heterogeneity between agents is quantified by their gradient disagreement:

â€–âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡Jâ„“â€‹(x)â€–â‰¤Gnormâˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ½â„“ğ‘¥ğº\|\nabla J_{k}(x)-\nabla J_{\ell}(x)\|\leq G (25)

Furthermore, the costs themselves are assumed to be Lipschitz, implying uniformly bounded gradient:

â€–âˆ‡Jkâ€‹(x)â€–â‰¤Unormâˆ‡subscriptğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘ˆ\|\nabla J_{k}(x)\|\leq U (26)

and the stochastic approximations of the gradient are Lipschitz in the mean-fourth sense:

\Eâ€‹{â€–âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\x)âˆ’âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\y)â€–4|\x,\y}â‰¤Î´^4â€‹â€–\xâˆ’\yâ€–4\Econditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’\xsuperscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’\y4\x\ysuperscript^ğ›¿4superscriptnorm\x\y4\E\left\{{\left\|\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\x)-\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\y)\right\|}^{4}|\x,\y\right\}\leq\hat{\delta}^{4}\left\|\x-\y\right\|^{4} (27)

3.3 Second-Order Guarantees

Examination of the boundsÂ (28)â€“(30) reveals that the aggregate zero-mean component \sisubscript\sğ‘–\s_{i} arising from the use of stochastic gradient approximations continues to be bounded in a manner similar to the local approximationsÂ (13), where the aggregate constant bounds are determined by the quality of local approximations {Î²k4,Ïƒk4}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘˜4superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜4ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\beta_{k}^{4},\sigma_{k}^{4}\}_{k=1}^{K}, the participation rate LKğ¿ğ¾\frac{L}{K}, the weights {pk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{p_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}, the level of heterogeneity GğºG, and number of local updates taken Eksubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜E_{k}. The bias ğ’…isubscriptğ’…ğ‘–\boldsymbol{d}_{i} induced by employing multiple local updates, on the other hand, does not have zero-mean. The bound on its fourth-order momentÂ (30), however, is proportional to Î¼4superscriptğœ‡4\mu^{4}, causing its effect to be small for small step-sizes when compared to \sisubscript\sğ‘–\s_{i}, which is independent in Î¼ğœ‡\mu. The fact that ğ’…isubscriptğ’…ğ‘–\boldsymbol{d}_{i} is biased renders traditional second-order analysis of stochastic gradient algorithmsÂ [4, 5, 6, 1, 8] inapplicable to this setting, while the fact that its fourth-order moment is small compared to \sisubscript\sğ‘–\s_{i} makes it possible to extend the arguments ofÂ [1, 8]. {theorem} Suppose the aggregate loss Jâ€‹(w)ğ½ğ‘¤J(w) is bounded from below by Jâ€‹(w)â‰¥Joğ½ğ‘¤superscriptğ½ğ‘œJ(w)\geq J^{o}. Then, with probability 1âˆ’2â€‹Ï€12ğœ‹1-2\pi:

â€–âˆ‡Jâ€‹(\wio)â€–2â‰¤Î¼â€‹Î´â€‹ÏƒÂ¯21âˆ’2â€‹Î¼â€‹Î´â€‹(1+Î²Â¯2)â€‹(1+1Ï€)+Oâ€‹(Î¼2)superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œ2ğœ‡ğ›¿superscriptÂ¯ğœ212ğœ‡ğ›¿1superscriptÂ¯ğ›½211ğœ‹ğ‘‚superscriptğœ‡2\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq\mu\frac{\delta\overline{\sigma}^{2}}{1-2\mu\delta(1+\overline{\beta}^{2})}\left(1+\frac{1}{\pi}\right)+O(\mu^{2}) (37)

and Î»minâ€‹(âˆ‡2Jâ€‹(\wio))â‰¥âˆ’Ï„subscriptğœ†superscriptâˆ‡2ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œğœ\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau in at most iosuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œi^{o} iterations, where

ioâ‰¤2â€‹(Jâ€‹(w0)âˆ’Jo)Î¼2â€‹Î´â€‹ÏƒÂ¯2â€‹issuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œ2ğ½subscriptğ‘¤0superscriptğ½ğ‘œsuperscriptğœ‡2ğ›¿superscriptÂ¯ğœ2superscriptğ‘–ğ‘ \displaystyle i^{o}\leq\frac{2\left(J(w_{0})-J^{o}\right)}{\mu^{2}\delta\overline{\sigma}^{2}}i^{s} (38)

and issuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘ i^{s} denotes the saddle-point escape time:

is=logâ¡(2â€‹Mâ€‹ÏƒÂ¯2ÏƒÂ¯â„“2+1+Oâ€‹(Î¼))logâ€‹(1+2â€‹Î¼â€‹Ï„)superscriptğ‘–ğ‘ 2ğ‘€superscriptÂ¯ğœ2superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœâ„“21ğ‘‚ğœ‡log12ğœ‡ğœ\displaystyle i^{s}=\frac{\log\left(2M\frac{{\overline{\sigma}^{2}}}{{\overline{\sigma}_{\ell}^{2}}}+1+O(\mu)\right)}{\mathrm{log}\left(1+2\mu\tau\right)} (39)
{proof}

The argument is an adjustment ofÂ [8] by bounding away the effect of ğ’…isubscriptğ’…ğ‘–\boldsymbol{d}_{i}. Details omitted due to space limitations. This result ensures that, with probability 1âˆ’2â€‹Ï€12ğœ‹1-2\pi, the FedAvg algorithm will return a second-order stationary point with â€–âˆ‡Jâ€‹(\wio)â€–2â‰¤Oâ€‹(Î¼)superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œ2ğ‘‚ğœ‡\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq O(\mu) and Î»minâ€‹(âˆ‡2Jâ€‹(\wio))â‰¥âˆ’Ï„subscriptğœ†superscriptâˆ‡2ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œğœ\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau in at most iosuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œi^{o} iterations, where iosuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œi^{o} scales polynomially with all problem parameters. Every second-order stationary point, in light of â€–âˆ‡Jâ€‹(\wio)â€–2â‰¤Oâ€‹(Î¼)superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œ2ğ‘‚ğœ‡\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq O(\mu) is also first-order stationary, but the additional condition Î»minâ€‹(âˆ‡2Jâ€‹(\wio))â‰¥âˆ’Ï„subscriptğœ†superscriptâˆ‡2ğ½subscript\wsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘œğœ\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau allows for the exclusion of strict saddle-points by choosing Ï„ğœ\tau sufficiently small.

This loss arises when training a neural network with a single, linear hidden layer to predict the class label ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma} from ğ’‰ğ’‰\boldsymbol{h} using cross-entropy, and exhibits a strict saddle-point at w1=W2=0subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘Š20w_{1}=W_{2}=0, making it suitable as a simplified benchmark â€” seeÂ [9] for a discussion and motivation. with probability pk=0.5subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0.5p_{k}=0.5, and âˆ‡J^keâ€‹(\wk,eâˆ’1)=0superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ½ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscript\wğ‘˜ğ‘’10\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=0 otherwise. Evolution of iterates and the gradient norm are shown in FiguresÂ 1 andÂ 2 respectively.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we considered a highly heterogeneous and asynchronous variant of the Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm, where agents may be using varying, potentially unreliable, stochastic gradient approximations with varying quality, and take a different number Eksubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜E_{k} of local update steps, and established convergence to second-order stationary points. Despite high levels of heterogeneity and asynchrony, the algorithm continues to escape saddle-points and return second-order stationary points in polynomial time, shedding light on the success of deep learning, which is frequently employed in federated learning settings.
